name: Guam
background: Guam was ceded to the US by Spain in 1898. Captured by the Japanese in 1941, it was retaken by the US three years later. The military installation on the island is one of the most strategically important US bases in the Pacific.

geo.Location: Oceania, island in the North Pacific Ocean, about three-quarters of the way from Hawaii to the Philippines
geo.Area - comparative: three times the size of Washington, DC
geo.Terrain: volcanic origin, surrounded by coral reefs; relatively flat coralline limestone plateau (source of most fresh water), with steep coastal cliffs and narrow coastal plains in north, low hills in center, mountains in south
geo.Natural hazards: frequent squalls during rainy season; relatively rare but potentially destructive typhoons (June - December)
environmentalIssues: extirpation of native bird population by the rapid proliferation of the brown tree snake, an exotic, invasive species
climate: generally warm and humid, moderated by northeast trade winds
dry season (January to June), rainy season (July to December)
geographyNote: largest and southernmost island in the Mariana Islands archipelago
strategic location in western North Pacific Ocean

Literacy.definition: age 15 and over can read and write

government.Dependency status: organized, unincorporated territory of the US with policy relations between Guam and the US under the jurisdiction of the Office of Insular Affairs, US Department of the Interior

Capital.name: Hagatna (Agana)
Capital.time difference: UTC+10 (15 hours ahead of Washington, DC during Standard Time)

government.National holiday: Discovery Day, first Monday in March (1521)
government.Legal system: common law modeled on US system; US federal laws apply
government.Suffrage: 18 years of age; universal; US citizens but do not vote in US presidential elections

Executive branch.chief of state: President Barack H. OBAMA (since 20 January 2009); Vice President Joseph R. BIDEN (since 20 January 2009)
Executive branch.head of government: Governor Eddie CALVO (since 3 January 2011); Lieutenant Governor Ray TENORIO (since 3 January 2011)
Executive branch.cabinet: heads of executive departments; appointed by the governor with the consent of the Guam legislature
Executive branch.elections: under the US Constitution, residents of unincorporated territories, such as Guam, do not vote in elections for US president and vice president; however, they may vote in Democratic and Republican presidential primary elections; governor and lieutenant governor elected on the same ticket by popular vote for a four-year term (can serve two consecutive terms, then must wait a full term before running again); election last held on 2 November 2010 (next to be held in November 2014)
Executive branch.election results: Eddie CALVO elected governor with 50.6% percent of vote against 49.4% for Carl GUTIERREZ; Ray TENORIO elected lieutenant governor

Legislative branch.Legislative branch: unicameral Legislature (15 seats; members elected by popular vote to serve two-year terms)
Legislative branch.elections: last held on 2 November 2010 (next to be held in November 2012)
Legislative branch.election results: percent of vote by party - NA; seats by party - Democratic Party 9, Republican Party 6

government.Judicial branch: Federal District Court (judge is appointed by the president); Supreme Court of Guam (hears appeals from Superior Court - judges appointed by governor); Territorial Superior Court (judges appointed for eight-year terms by the governor)
government.Political parties and leaders: Democratic Party [Michael PHILLIPS]; Republican Party [Philip J. FLORES] (controls the legislature)

Political pressure groups and leaders.Political pressure groups and leaders: Guam Federation of Teachers' Union; Guam Waterworks Authority Workers

Flag description.Flag description: territorial flag is dark blue with a narrow red border on all four sides; centered is a red-bordered, pointed, vertical ellipse containing a beach scene, a proa or outrigger canoe with sail, and a palm tree with the word GUAM superimposed in bold red letters; the proa is sailing in Agana Bay with the promontory of Punta Dos Amantes, near the capital, in the background; blue represents the sea and red the blood shed in the struggle against oppression

National anthem.name: "Fanohge Chamoru" (Stand Ye Guamanians)
National anthem.lyrics/music: Ramon Manalisay SABLAN [English], Lagrimas UNTALAN [Chamoru]/Ramon Manalisay SABLAN

economy.Economy - overview: The economy depends largely on US military spending and tourism. Total US grants, wage payments, and procurement outlays amounted to $1.3 billion in 2004. Over the past 30 years, the tourist industry has grown to become the largest income source following national defense. The Guam economy continues to experience expansion in both its tourism and military sectors.
industries: US military, tourism, construction, transshipment services, concrete products, printing and publishing, food processing, textiles

Telephone system.general assessment: modern system, integrated with US facilities for direct dialing, including free use of 800 numbers
Telephone system.domestic: digital system, including mobile-cellular service and local access to the Internet
Telephone system.international: country code - 1-671; major landing point for submarine cables between Asia and the US (Guam is a trans-Pacific communications hub for major carriers linking the US and Asia); satellite earth stations - 2 Intelsat (Pacific Ocean)

communications.Broadcast media: about a dozen TV broadcast channels, including digital channels; multi-channel cable TV services are available; roughly 20 radio stations broadcasting (2009)

military.Military - note: defense is the responsibility of the US
